text: Dear David, I see at least two fundamental points very different from you and i think we have reasons to see a bright future for the next generations. My first point where I radically differ from you is regarding the (minor) role of CO2 as a greenhouse gas and my second point is that you do not take in account the eminent role of the water vapor feed-back, which is crucial in all the IPCC models to justify the projected potentially extremely high temperature increases till end of the century of up to 4.5 degrees C and higher. Regarding the role of CO2 for the Climate Change S.I. Rasool and S.H. Schneider (the later co-founder of IPCC), both from NASA GISS, created with a 1971 groundbreaking SCIENCE Article the base of all IPCC models. They stated: " A doubling of CO2 produces a tropospheric temperature change of 0.8 K (or 0.8 degrees C). However as more CO2 is added to the atmosphere the rate of temperature increase is proportionally less and less and the increase eventually levels off. Even for an increase in CO2 by a factor of 10 (!), the temperature increase does not exceed 2.5 K (or 2.5 degrees C). Therefore, the runaway greenhouse effect does not occur because the 15 Œºm CO2 band, which is the main source of absorption, saturates." This NASA Report was later confirmed by 40 years satellite and 70 years of weather balloon temperature measurements. We should therefore relax and enjoy the advantages of higher CO2 concentrations of more than 400 ppm, as is the greening of the planet which already measurably helps to improve the food production and greens the Sahel. More vegetation is also essential for the functioning of the hydrological cycles and the above-mentioned water vapor feed-back is part of these cycles. The hydrological cycles govern up to 95% of the earth heat dynamics and energy fluxes. These are self-organizing interconnected systems stabilizing the climate since 4.5 billion years despite dramatically changing CO2 concentrations in Earth‚Äôs history from 100 ppm to 10.000 ppm. The water vapor feed-back is usually explained the following way: The increase of the greenhouse gas CO2 in the atmosphere causes a certain small temperature increase. A warmer atmosphere can hold more water vapor, which is the most important greenhouse gas, and this water vapor causes again an additional warming of the atmosphere. But it is essential to mention and almost always forgotten, that this increased concentration of water vapor condenses to clouds, which then reflect up to 90% of the incoming solar radiation back to space. As the 15- Œºm absorption band is more and more saturated the greenhouse effect of the CO2 is levelling off and I suppose that the negative cloud feed-back already begins to dominate the positive water vapor feed-back and the net effect will be a cooling. Taking this into account the greenhouse effect of doubling of the CO2 concentration in the atmosphere, which will be reached probably end of the century, is not more than 1.2 ‚Äì 1.5 degrees C. This temperature increase would be only beneficial ‚Äì remember that in 1850 we came out of the Little Ice Age and the temperatures have not yet reached the optimal temperature of the Holocene of 15-degree C. During the Holocene Optimum 9800 until 5800 years before our time the average temperatures on the Northern Hemisphere were about 1-5 degrees C warmer than today, the Earth biosphere was flourishing, and the Humans started the first High Civilizations. I suppose the North Pole was ice free during these 4000 (!) years and the permafrost thawed completely in the Tundra. The mentioned complex processes of the hydrological cycles are utterly impossible to model. The IPCC climate scientists try therefore since 1980 in vain to lower the prohibitive high uncertainty range of 1.5. to 4.5 degrees C for a doubling of CO2. All simulated projections of temperature by the IPCC models showed a heavily exaggerated warming. About twice as much as measured by 40 years of satellite and 70 years of weather balloon measurements. All models would have to be considered falsified, if real Science would be applied. The sea level rise depends to 50% on the ocean expansion caused by the warming of the atmosphere. To my understanding, this warming is impossible to foresee based on the IPCC models. My projection is that sea level will go on to rise modestly, as it did the last 12000 years, about 3 mm per year. That means about 25 cm until end of century ‚Äì no big deal. We will see.
author: Matth√§us LIll

text:
Dear David, I see at least two fundamental points very different from you and i think we have reasons to see a bright future for the next generations. My first point where I radically differ from you is regarding the (minor) role of CO2 as a greenhouse gas and my second point is that you do not take in account the eminent role of the water vapor feed-back, which is crucial in all the IPCC models to justify the projected potentially extremely high temperature increases till end of the century of up to 4.5 degrees C and higher. 

Regarding the role of CO2 for the Climate Change S.I. Rasool and S.H. Schneider (the later co-founder of IPCC), both from NASA GISS, created with a 1971 groundbreaking SCIENCE Article the base of all IPCC models. They stated: 
" A doubling of CO2 produces a tropospheric temperature change of 0.8 K (or 0.8 degrees C). However as more CO2 is added to the atmosphere the rate of temperature increase is proportionally less and less and the increase eventually levels off. Even for an increase in CO2 by a factor of 10 (!), the temperature increase does not exceed 2.5 K (or 2.5 degrees C). Therefore, the runaway greenhouse effect does not occur because the 15 Œºm CO2 band, which is the main source of absorption, saturates." 
This NASA Report was later confirmed by 40 years satellite and 70 years of weather balloon temperature measurements. We should therefore relax and enjoy the advantages of higher CO2 concentrations of more than 400 ppm, as is the greening of the planet which already measurably helps to improve the food production and greens the Sahel. 

More vegetation is also essential for the functioning of the hydrological cycles and the above-mentioned water vapor feed-back is part of these cycles. The hydrological cycles govern up to 95% of the earth heat dynamics and energy fluxes. These are self-organizing interconnected systems stabilizing the climate since 4.5 billion years despite dramatically changing CO2 concentrations in Earth‚Äôs history from 100 ppm to 10.000 ppm. The water vapor feed-back is usually explained the following way:
The increase of the greenhouse gas CO2 in the atmosphere causes a certain small temperature increase. A warmer atmosphere can hold more water vapor, which is the most important greenhouse gas, and this water vapor causes again an additional warming of the atmosphere. But it is essential to mention and almost always forgotten, that this increased concentration of water vapor condenses to clouds, which then reflect up to 90% of the incoming solar radiation back to space. As the 15- Œºm absorption band is more and more saturated the greenhouse effect of the CO2 is levelling off and I suppose that the negative cloud feed-back already begins to dominate the positive water vapor feed-back and the net effect will be a cooling. Taking this into account the greenhouse effect of doubling of the CO2 concentration in the atmosphere, which will be reached probably end of the century, is not more than 1.2 ‚Äì 1.5 degrees C. This temperature increase would be only beneficial ‚Äì remember that in 1850 we came out of the Little Ice Age and the temperatures have not yet reached the optimal temperature of the Holocene of 15-degree C.  During the Holocene Optimum 9800 until 5800 years before our time the average temperatures on the Northern Hemisphere were about 1-5 degrees C warmer than today, the Earth biosphere was flourishing, and the Humans started the first High Civilizations. I suppose the North Pole was ice free during these 4000 (!) years and the permafrost thawed completely in the Tundra.

The mentioned complex processes of the hydrological cycles are utterly impossible to model. The IPCC climate scientists try therefore since 1980 in vain to lower the prohibitive high uncertainty range of 1.5. to 4.5 degrees C for a doubling of CO2. All simulated projections of temperature by the IPCC models showed a heavily exaggerated warming. About twice as much as measured by 40 years of satellite and 70 years of weather balloon measurements. All models would have to be considered falsified, if real Science would be applied.

The sea level rise depends to 50% on the ocean expansion caused by the warming of the atmosphere. To my understanding, this warming is impossible to foresee based on the IPCC models. My projection is that sea level will go on to rise modestly, as it did the last 12000 years, about 3 mm per year. That means about 25 cm until end of century ‚Äì no big deal. We will see.

text:
Is climate change real or false? forget all the scientists and there graphs and figures, just deal with basic physics.

The answer lies in two simple laws of physics.

Physic law one)  

It is physically impossible to endlessly put something into something that is not endless.   Regardless of the size of the limited space there is no exception to this law, if it is a limited space then you cannot endlessly put something into it.

If that limited space as a ecosystem that relies on balance then every species in it must be kept to a acceptable number that, that ecosystem can naturally support.

But that is not what the human species wants to do,  it wants to put an endless amount of people into this limited space and claims it will not damage or upset the natural balance of this limited space. This is because it cannot deal with  population control,  it doesn't have the emotional ability or the intelligence to discuss such a subject . It is why it is living in denial. 

 Physics law two)

It is physically impossible for a stationary object to keep up with something that is constantly moving.  No matter how far a head you put the stationary object of the thing that is moving it will always catch it up and leave it behind.
Now you can always keep moving the stationary object ahead of the thing that's moving, but to do so you will have to have endless space, if you don't have endless space then you are going to come unstuck.

This should tell you,  it doesn't matter how many homes you build you will never build enough, because the problem will keep coming back as the population keeps growing.

 The quicker the population grows the quicker the problem comes back, so building homes is not the answer.

The answer is to stop the thing that is moving and keep it level with the stationary object then you have solved the problem for ever until the end of time. 

 So if you control the human population and keep it at a sensible level that each landmass can naturally support,  then you don't have problems because you are keeping the human species in balance with its environment. 

These two laws show you that climate change is real because you have a species just mindlessly endlessly multiplying into a space that is not endless, there can only be one outcome from this behaviour. And it is not a good one .

If anybody thinks I am wrong then I challenge you to prove me wrong,  get a limited space like a cup, then show me how you can endlessly pour water into it without it ever overflowing. Without trickery , And I will admit I am wrong.

I really don't get it. He breaks it down fairly simply. By throwing millions of tons of carbon in the air we are changing the chemical composition of earth's atmosphere. There is unyielding science that shows the result of that process will make our planet uninhabitable for humans if not reversed. Do you honestly disagree with that assessment?

text: I like the part at about the 1:10 mark where he acknowledges most alarmists find the effort of actually becoming educated on the topic to be "too dreary".   Then he proceeds to give a presentation without any factual backing, just making claims... like someone who find the effort to actually learn details about the science "too dreary".  He could have talked about the predictive capability of the climate models (or lack of), or the fact that CO2's warming potential falls off rapidly as more is added to the atmosphere since it only absorb a narrow band of the IR radiation wave spectrum and by about 200ppm has absorbed about all it can absorb, or the fact that the models completely ignore the impact  of clouds and areosols.  He didn't mention the 0.8C of warming began as the earth was coming out of a period of natural cooling (the Little Ice Age), and the definition of "coming out of a cooling period" would imply warming... and that that warming began naturally before any consumption of fossil fuels.  He could have mentioned that between 12000 and 7000 years ago sea levels rose 400 feet which all happened naturally... but over the lat 200 years sea levels have only risen about 13.5 inches (2mm per year which is about 1/12 of an inch).  So 400 feet by nature, but  that extreme and catastrophic 13.6 inches is man made... yea that makes sense.  How about the fact that the glaciers in Glacier National Park began forming about 7000  years ago during a time when there were maybe 5 million humans and significantly lower levels of CO2... today we have year-round ice at Glacier National Park along with 6.5 billion people, 1 billion cars and significantly higher levels of CO2.  It was warmer 7000 years ago with much less CO2 than today with much more CO2.  What else is there to say really... clearly something other than CO2 is driving climate and the "climate change alarmists" don't understand what it is.

text:
Under clear skies with little wind, the 
sun went down and I noticed the temperature dropped by several 
degrees(probably 2-3 degrees within 
30-40 minutes following sunset). About an hour later with no wind, high 
level clouds formed overhead. Not long after, I noticed the 
temperature rise by several degrees, perhaps about 2 degrees. 

¬†My point is that CO2 did not trap enough heat radiated from the Earth to 
overcome radiational cooling once 
the sun went down under clear skies, which caused the temperature to 
drop.¬† However,¬† the formation of high level clouds significantly 
overwhelmed radiational cooling by trapping noticeable heat from the 
Earth resulting in a rise in temperature.
It is reasonable to believe from this test that CO2 is not even close to 
being a strong greenhouse gas that can trap heat to affect our 
weather............it provided no noticeable warming and allowed cooling
 to predominate in the absence of clouds 

All temperatures were read off of my car's
 outside thermometer with the car parked at the same location for about 1 and 1/2 hours.

text:
Climate change ?? In the 21st century we humans like believing we "have the power" to be in total control of everything and hate to think certain facets of our comfortable life could scare us. 
So if we don't like climate events just¬† look for some man made activity to blame rather than admit our vulnerability to what is beyond our control. If we can nominate some human activity then government can tax it and some institution will inevitably seek funding to "solve" it. 
But why the heck should anyone expect long range climate patterns to be static. Look at the record for climate over the past 500mill years. We survive on a very small, unique, fragile rock hurtling thru space in an imperfect orbit around a star that converts 5 mill tons of mass into energy every 
second. Occasionally sunspots and flaring occur, our magnetic poles change, tectonic plates affect islands and even continents, earthquakes¬† and tsunamis, undersea volcanoes (some 75,000) rise up to a kilometer, heating the oceans with lava affecting sea pH, temperature and levels. And some complain that it's all man induced with oceans perhaps having risen an inch and¬† global¬† temperatures increased a degree over past100yrs all bc of man's activities?¬† Then these ill informed, carbon based doomsayers, aka green zombies and control freaks look for someone or something¬† to blame. So they wrongly¬† complain that CO2 is a pollutant and not the sustainer of all lifeforms and the reason the earth is not a desolate, lifeless wasteland, like every other planet in the universe. But how else do these self defined semi evolved apes glorify an otherwise meaningless existence and get on TV?

This is so wrong. We have 400 ppm CO2 in the atmosphere now. The Earth was lush and covered with jungle and dinosaurs when CO2 was at 2000 ppm, and all the way up to 6000 ppm. CO2 levels are an effect of climate change, not a cause! More CO2 does not cause more IR absorption and retention of heat, as the IR absorption has already reached its maximum. It's like adding more salt to a brine solution, it doesn't make the brine any saltier. Climate change is happening, it has always happened, it always will happen. Human generated CO2 has nothing to do with climate change. All the carbon in the fossil fuels, perma-frost methane, carbonates in limestone/fossilized coral, was once in the atmosphere. The Earth is not going to become a desert from CO2 (maybe from the currently badly-designed nuclear reactors melting down, though, see the alternative thorium MSRs).

text:
CO2 Does Not Absorb Heat. Neither Does H2O. 
     Photonics Physics shows the following: 
In the 2.0 to 2.5 micron band of the IR, H2O vapors (75% RH) capture all the emitted radiation within 30 cm of the source and then dumps it to the atmosphere as Kinetic Energy (supersonic collisions of air molecules yields this transfer from the excited IR state). CO2 follows the same physics but at a lower level as due to it's low 300 to 400 ppm concentration, it takes about 33 meters for CO@ to capture all the available IR and convert it to velocity.
     CO2 cannot store energy. CO2 cannot store heat.
Near the earth's surface these molecules convert all the available IR emissions within 33 meters. There is insubstantial re-emission of IR photons.
     The Earth does not heat because of atmospheric IR back radiation.

text:
The Earth is not warming because of human CO2 emissions. This may surprise you, but you already know this. No, you don't have to be a climatologist with a string of letters after your name. All you need is to know a little basic history and not live in the tropics. There are two basic lies being put about. The hockey stick graph from Michael Mann and the overstating of the greenhouse effect of CO2 by the media.

Michael Mann from the IPCC produced a graph of the average temperature of the Earth over the last 1,000 years. This graph shows virtually no change in global temperatures from 1,000 years ago to the start of the industrial revolution at which point, driven by human CO2 emissions, it shoots up by, wait for it, an astronomic zero point eight degrees. In case you are wondering why anyone took this seriously, the entire Y axis he used was only about 1.5 degrees which made the 0.8 degree rise look huge and the media, always keen to¬†jump on a good scare story, ignored the scale. The real problem with his graph, however, is the assertion that the temperature remained constant prior to the industrial revolution. You know that just isn't true. In the tenth century, the Vikings, led by Erik the Red, settled and farmed in Greenland. It was much warmer then. When the Earth cooled some 4 to 5 hundred years later they had to leave. By 1600, the Earth was in the grip of a mini ice age. Seas around Britain's shores froze, and there were regular winter fairs held on the frozen river Thames. George the 2nd then enjoyed a considerable warming period, almost back to today's level. However, by the time Charles Dickens wrote Scrooge and A Christmas Carol the temperature had again dropped and white Christmases were the norm. None of this is the stuff of legend. It is all well documented.¬†The Michael Mann graph is just plain wrong, and, at no time during these changes was there any significant change in sea level.

The second lie is that the Earth is kept warm by the greenhouse effect of CO2. This is nonsense and, provided you don't live in the tropics, you know this too. Go outside on a winter night when it's cloudy and it's quite warm. Go outside when it's a clear starry night and it's cold. I'm not talking about 0.8 degrees here. There is a difference of 6 to 10 degrees. The greenhouse effect is caused by clouds. Yes, CO2 does have greenhouse properties but consider this, the concentration of CO2 in the air is a balance between what is emitted by us and volcanoes and¬† what is absorbed by plants, the oceans and crustaceans. On a weekday, our power stations work at full capacity, belching CO2, to run our factories, belching CO2, and 100,000 trucks thunder up and down motorways also belching CO2. At weekends the factories close and the truck drivers go fishing. The plants oceans and crustaceans don't have weekends off so by Sunday night the CO2 concentration is less than it was on Friday night. Now compare the temperature on a cold starry Friday night with the temperature on a cold starry Sunday night. Feel the difference? Of course not. Now we really are talking about a fraction of a degree. The greenhouse effect of CO2 is minimal compared to that of clouds. 

Don't forget that CO2 is essential to life on Earth. The planet's core is cooling. The more it cools, the less volcanic activity there is. The less volcanic activity there is, the less CO2 there is. Two hundred million years ago the CO2 level was about 2,000 parts per million. Today, it is only about 400 parts per million and 100 of that is only because of our burning fossil fuels. Any attempt to reduce CO2 emissions is not just silly, it's downright dangerous. Please stop worrying about man made global warming. If you want to worry about climate change, worry about the next ice age. The next ice age will kill you.

text:
Sorry but, he lost me at "The Medieval Ice Age".  His ignorance of basic climate science is shocking.

1.  Climate has not been "stable for the past 10,000 years".  Not unless you want to completely ignore things like the Holocene Climatic Optimum, the Roman Warm Period, the Medieval Warm period and the intervening cooling periods like the Little Ice Age.

2.  While he is correct that temperatures have been warming since the beginning of the Industrial Revolution, human emissions of CO2 didn't become globally significant until the middle of the 20th century.  Thus, to blame all of the warming since the end of the LIA on anthropogenic CO2 is absurd.

3.  2C of warming is hardly dangerous.  During the Holocene Climatic Optimum, temperatures were about 2C warmer than they are today and living things not only survived but thrived.  In fact, from 18,000BCE to about 4,400BCE, average global temperatures increased by nearly 6C.

4.  2C is not "off the table".   According to actual science (as opposed to career politicians like James Hansen), the sensitivity of the global climate system to a doubling of CO2 is, at best, 1C.  It is probably less, but let's stick with a nice, round number. 

In other words, in order to raise global temperatures by 1C, you would have to double the amount of CO2 in the atmosphere.  The effect of CO2 on temperature is logarithmic.  So, once you double CO2 levels, you have to double them again to get another 1C of warming.   To get 2C of warming, we would have to quadruple CO2 levels.  Nobody seriously thinks that going to happen.

5.  6C is ludicrous.  There isn't enough coal or oil on the planet to raise CO2 that high...  I'm done with this guy.

text:
OK, firstly a nuclear winter proves the point that changing the climate quickly has many drastic secondary effects. 
Next, it's ridiculous to think 0.03% of scientists could write every single climate paper that hasn't been rejected by pier review. 
As for how it's possible, it's a chemical property of greenhouse gases to absorb heat (energy from the infrared part of the spectrum). We are adding a whole lot more of them into the atmosphere. From CO2 bubbles trapped in ice we can tell that the CO2 level fluctuated between 200 and 280 ppm for the past 400,000 years. Until it started steadily rising along with our CO2 emissions (there are other gases but far more CO2 is produced than any other). 

There has been a slight between emissions and CO2 levels. Why? Because CO2 stays in the atmosphere for a very long period of time. Imagine a river of CO2 running into a lake of our atmosphere. The only problem is that it is nothing like that because it is constantly recycled back into the atmosphere thanks to the carbon cycle.

Lastly, 2016 was the hottest year on record, reaching at least 1.2 degrees Celsius above pre-industrial temperatures (New Scientist). 2015 was the hottest year before that. Guess what? 2014 was the hottest year even before that. That is somewhat to be expected because of the El Ni√±o cycle, but still, several other years have exceeded the 1998 record setting average temperature. It was also a very strong El Ni√±o event, however the global land temperature anomaly was only 0.93 degrees C above the 20th century average, compared to a 1.43 degree anomaly in 2016 (NOAA). (Yes, water does heat slower than land, and it was still above the '98 average).

One last thing, solar activity has been on the decline while the climate has been on the incline. Even the effects of a grand solar minimum, the last one of which coincided with the little ice age... caused only 0.4 degrees of cooling. Considering we are heading for 6 degrees of warming by 2100 solar activity is irrelevant.
Our entire civilization, from the wheel to agriculture and the iphone, arose from a period of climatic stability, varying about 1 degree in 12,000 years. Fun fact: if you admit the ice is melting quickly, you admit that the temperature is rising quickly, unless you believe that Europe was a glacier until the middle ages.

Which means a 3,000 calorie diet in the US is actually 3,000,000 calorie diet.
Fun fact #3: Galileo had facts to support him. Facts based on observation. He is pretty much irrelevant to your cause because you have not yet provided a single pertinent fact.

An open letter by scientists surrounding the ill-fated american people:
"One vexing and ongoing concern about climate change is the discrepancy between the public view about climate change and the view of climate scientists. Approximately 97% of active, publishing climate scientists believe4 in anthropogenic climate change (Doran and Zimmerman 2009, Anderegg et al 2010) and about 97% of papers published about climate change with an explicit position on the existence of climate change affirm that it is occurring (Cook et al 2013). However, only approximately half of the American public believes in anthropogenic climate change (Leiserowitz et al 2010, Weber and Stern 2011). There are many reasons for public doubt in climate change, including cognitive and affective factors (Gifford 2011, McCright and Dunlap 2011) and media coverage that gives undue weight to the climate change controversy (Boykoff and Boykoff 2004, Boykoff 2007) or is influenced by political ideology (Dotson et al 2012)."

-The climate change consensus extends beyond climate scientists, 
letter, J S Carlton1,3, Rebecca Perry-Hill1, Matthew Huber2 and Linda S Prokopy1

text:
You have not quoted any known science, which leads me to believe you are just improvising.

Look at the correlation between CO2 and temperature. This is known science, and it is also fact that CO2 absorbs infrared radiation (heat)

Burning fossil fuels produces CO2 in a combustion reaction. Chemistry is a known scientific field.

Consider that for the past 400,000 years CO2 levels were between 200 and 280 ppm (Vostok ice core data), and now they are consistently over 400 ppm. This is data confirmed with the power of science.
(There is always a slight delay between CO2 and temperature, caused by 
1 delayed effect of CO2 and its longevity 
2 positive feedback loops (runaway warming))

Finally, consider the fact that we can measure how much CO2 we emit, and it is consistent with the increase in ppm. 

Please, tell me which fact is wrong, or stop wasting my time. It doesn't matter if we warm by 4 degrees or 6 degrees Celsius by 2100, it's still going to be exact. What we can deduce however is that 
a) the climate is warming
b) we are the main cause for this

text:
+Stan lk It's complex, not simple so we have to look at the big picture and include more points of view. Water vapour is an important factor but I think it's been stable; the changing factor is the CO2, which also increases the water vapour - a positive feedback loop! 
There may be hospitals or cases that have not been able to use electricity because of no alternatives for coal. That doesn't change the likelihood that increased CO2 global warming unchecked can lead to many more deaths than there have ever been people in hospital. And could lead to species extinction for us. 
Trying to look at the big picture . . . best wishes!

text: It's been a while since I've seen him speak, but the author of "Thin Ice" described the famous "hockey stick curve". Ice core samples proved the predictable pattern of "natural" global warming (as it was seen before we came along - CO2 measurements in the air bubbles of very deep ice core samples - each layer representing a normal winter freeze/thaw cycle) that preceded each ice age. The scientists prove with very boring data/detail that there has always been a cycle of warming and then cooling. Unfortunately, the earth's way of finding this balance is violent; a warming of the earth's core resulting in even more unstable crust/fault-lines cascading to huge volcanic eruptions which darken the atmosphere so very little solar energy can enter. What follows is ice covering the majority of the earth's surface. Leading up to that moment are more and more earth-quakes, especially under the oceans leading to¬†tsunami's that are starting to become even more and more commonplace today. The next ice age happens without our help. Global warming and cooling is a natural cycle that is a wonder of the nature of this earth. But the ice core samples prove that we have accelerated the CO2 levels faster than any other cycle. I ask the nay sayers a different question. What do we have to lose by making positive changes - from which we all benefit. There's a real chance another issue exists - which is peak oil. text:
I'm gonna take a stab at this and see what happens, but I kinda know already.....here goes.

I have never once said that climate change is not happening. The climate has changed, to extremes, ever since there has been an atmosphere, for some 1 billion years. Life on earf has been around for some 600 million years. There have been at least 5 extinction events that wiped out more than 50% of ALL life in that period, sometimes almost instantly, and man was never ever around to see it, participate in it, much less cause it. I use that to make my point. David Roberts believes that increased co2 in the atmosphere by even a tiny amount will be catastrophic. Historically speaking, and not just the last million years, co2 levels have been much much higher than they are now. The earf has had the most biodiversity when co2 levels were well over 1,000 ppm, more than twice what it is now. The highest concentrations of co2 were above 4,000 ppm during the Ordovician - Silurian and the Jurassic - Cretaceous periods, and life did just fine. So, historically speaking, current co2 levels are at least 10 times lower than in the past. The last extinction event, but smaller by comparison to the 5 largest, happened about 20,000 years ago when co2 levels dropped below 200 ppm. Our ancestors were almost wiped out. Plants did not prosper, so there was very very little to eat for any animals period. Plants prefer co2 levels above 1,000 ppm, that's why we raise them in green houses. The earf's biosphere adapts to changing climate, hence why the earf doesn't go over a tipping point like Venus, which is in a runaway greenhouse environment, and nothing can survive.
So why all the fuss about global warming, climate change and co2? I will tell you that it is not about saving the polar bears, saving the planet, saving the oysters, saving our coastlines or saving humanity. It is about power and control. It is about powerful all encompassing government control of our lives because we are not capable of making proper choices for ourselves. We are too stupid. Just ask Jonathan Gruber, the architect of Obamacare.
If the only cure to stop anthropogenic global warming didn't involve the extraction of money and wealth from individuals and nations, I would be less suspect. But, when you follow the money and government control infrastructure, the answer is clear.¬†

text:
The earth is about 4.2 billion years old.¬† For the relatively short time that humans have been on this earth the climate has been quite stable.¬† The atmospheric CO-2 concentration has been between 180 and 280 parts per million (ppm) for the period humans have been on the planet, except that recently we have bumped it up to 400 ppm by the addition of carbon from outside the biosphere.¬† The added CO-2 has caused many unusual events, but most importantly, has cause ice cover and snow cover to melt.¬† Keep in mind that the added CO-2 has thrown the planet‚Äôs heat balance out of whack.¬† The planet is now absorbing more heat from the sun than what is leaving.¬† As the snow and ice melts, the heat imbalance will get worse. The ultimate effect is beyond the human experience and therefore can‚Äôt be modeled or predicted with any acceptable level of confidence.¬† ¬†¬†
¬†
¬†
¬†The only real solution is not in reducing emissions but to get out the carbon we have put into the biosphere and sequester it.¬† Apparently the cost of scrubbing CO-2 from the atmosphere is between $100-200 per ton of carbon.¬† Worldwide we emit 33 billion tons of carbon to the atmosphere from anthropogenic sources each year.¬† The US is responsible for about 20% of this, or about 6.6 billion tons.¬† At a cost of say $150 per ton, we could remove all our annual emissions for about 0.99 trillion dollars per year.¬† Since we use 1.3 trillion gallons of gasoline each year, all that would be required to clean up all our emissions is a tax of 76 cents per gallon.¬† There is about 500 excess billion tons of carbon in the atmosphere and we would have to work to get rid of that also.¬† At a $150 per ton, that would cost 75 trillion dollars, something the whole world couldn‚Äôt afford, at least not over a one-year period.¬†¬† ¬†If there was a ten year plan, then the annual cost for annual emissions plus 10% of existing emissions would be 8.5 trillion dollars, which might be affordable.¬† If a lot of the ice and snow cover melts in the ten year period, we may need to bring the CO-2 level to below 280 ppm to get the planet‚Äôs heat flow back into balance.¬† ¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†
author: Walt P

text:
.¬† It is an interesting exercise to think about how climate changes could affect human life on the planet.¬† Here are some thoughts:
Scenario #1:¬† Releases for methane from the Arctic Ocean sediments.
Apparently the Arctic Ocean sediments have about 1.5 trillion tons of carbon in the form of methane locked up as methane-hydrate.¬† The methane-hydrate is kept bottled up by an underwater permafrost layer.¬† Just like oil, it has been there from millions of years.¬† A reasonable question is that if it has been there for millions of years why should we think that it will be released now.¬† The reason is that Arctic Ocean ice is melting and for the first time in human history this coming September (2015) there is expected to be zero ice covering the Arctic Ocean.¬† In subsequent years the ice is expected to be melted earlier and earlier.¬† In the summer the top of the earth is tilted toward the sun, thus instead of ice reflecting sunlight away from the planet, the dark water will absorb it warming the water column and then eventually the permafrost releasing the methane.¬† Since methane is about 77 times more powerful a greenhouse gas than is CO-2, the 1.5 trillion tons is equivalent to 115 trillion tons of carbon as CO-2.¬† The current excess of carbon in the atmosphere is about 0.5 trillion tons.¬† If only 10% of the Arctic methane is released, that would be equivalent to increasing the excess CO-2 in the atmosphere by a factor of 23, or 2300%.¬† This would be equivalent to a CO-2 concentration in the atmosphere of over 3000 ppm.¬† The current excess atmospheric CO-2 is causing all kinds of problems such as more extensive forest fires, more severe hurricanes and tornadoes, increased acidification of the ocean, and melting of glaciers, snow cover and ocean ice.¬†¬† It is hard to imagine that terrestrial life could survive such an event.¬† Also, it is so far beyond the human experience that accurate modeling is impossible. The unique thing about this scenario is that it could happen soon.¬†

Scenario #2:¬† Continued slow heating of the planet.
The heat balance of the planet is not in line with what it should be.¬† ¬†Over the last several million years, including the time humans have been on the planet, the heat coming in has been equal to that leaving the planet, at least when averaged over an ice-age cycle, or over periods of several years within an ice-age cycle.¬† While humans inhabited this planet we have had the benefit of a fairly consistent biosphere, or at least one that has been consistent enough for us to survive and adapt.¬† If the planet had an atmosphere that had no greenhouse gases in it, the average annual temperature has been estimated to be about 0 degrees Fahrenheit.¬† The CO-2 level in the atmosphere has oscillated between 180 and 280 parts per million, the lower number when the earth was in its coldest state of each ice age cycle and the higher number when it was in its warmest state.¬† The CO-2 level did not drive the temperature but followed it.¬† The temperature was driven by the precession of the earth‚Äôs orbit.¬† ¬†At this point in the current ice-age cycle the concentration of CO-2 should be about 280 parts per million, but because of humans using fossil fuels it is about 400 parts per million.¬† At 280 parts per million the average temperature has been measured to be about 57 degrees Fahrenheit.¬† Now that the CO-2 concentration is 400 parts per million, heat from sunlight is building up in the planet and the world average temperature is closer to 60 degrees Fahrenheit.¬† The excess heat mostly ends up in heating the oceans because water has a much larger heat capacity than does the atmosphere, so humans don‚Äôt notice it very much.¬† In addition to heating up the oceans, some of the heat goes into melting ice and heating the land.¬† Ice is important because it reflects sunlight back to space so helps to keep the planet cool.¬† As the ice disappears the heat imbalance will get even worse.¬† In addition, humans will continue adding CO-2 to the atmosphere, currently at a rate of 33 billion tons worldwide annually; thus, it is expected that heating will continue to rise until crops are affected, by drying out of the planet soils and by planet climate changes.¬† It is likely that the northern hemisphere will be affected first as there is much more ice in the Antarctic than in Greenland.¬† There will be significant food shortages and die-off of human populations.¬† Whether or not countries in the northern hemisphere will continue to exist and for how long is impossible to predict. At some point oil use will be significantly reduced because of large-scale death of humans, and the snowballing effect will slow down to some extent, and maybe the planet heat balance will come back into equilibrium over time, but that could only happen if the temperature of the ocean and land surfaces are significantly hotter to radiate heat back out to space.¬† Exactly how hot they have to be to bring the heat flow back into balance is unknown.¬† ¬†¬†
¬†
Scenario #3:¬† Death of the oceans and the rain forests.¬†¬†¬†¬†
The Amazon rain forests and the oceans are essentially the lungs of the planet.¬† They work to keep the balance between atmospheric CO-2 and O-2 constant.¬† The Amazon rain forests may be lost because of changing rainfall patterns.¬† Apparently they are currently under drought conditions.¬† The oceans are becoming more acid because of increased CO-2 in them.¬† CO-2 combines with a water molecule, H20 to produce H2CO3.¬† The H2CO3 molecule disassociates to H+ and HCO3-, thus there are more H+ molecules, or an increase in acidity.¬† Currently there are about 30% more H+ molecules in ocean waters than before humans started using fossil fuels.¬† There are several species of animals in the ocean that have to calcify their shells which becomes more difficult with increasing acidity.¬† If the oceans and/or the rain forests are seriously affected it is hard to imagine that the atmosphere will be stable enough for terrestrial life forms to continue to survive.

Take my challenge and tell me where Hansen is egregiously wrong in the following;

"OK, all you on your knees worshiping in the Church of Catastrophic Anthropogenic Global Warming, dutifully attacking apostasy and memorizing your catechism, here is ¬†one of your heroes in an unforced error. ¬†Let us see what kind of clever little children you are and see if you can spot the error that is emblematic of the whole field of Climate Science. ¬†At least the way it is practiced by the likes of Hansen, Mann, Trenberth and many others (and reported on like Naomi Kline) who have risen to the top of the public heap and many who are unknown who toil tirelessly in the basements of once great universities devising clever ways to get more funding. ¬†More Funding. ¬†MoreFunding!

Earth‚Äôs energy imbalance and implications (2011)‚Äù
http://www.atmos-chem-phys.net/11/13421/2011/acp-11-13421-2011.pdf

Hansen starts out describing the greenhouse effect:

‚ÄúThe basic physics underlying this global warming, the greenhouse effect, is simple. An increase of gases such as CO2 makes the atmosphere more opaque at infrared wavelengths. This added opacity causes the planet‚Äôs heat radiation to space to arise from higher, colder levels in the atmosphere, thus reducing emission of heat energy to space. The temporary imbalance between the energy absorbed from the Sun and heat emission to space, causes the planet to warm until planetary energy balance is restored.‚Äù

So we have this alleged energy imbalance that is causing the planet to warm. The scientific method requires that one conduct experiments or perform measurements to confirm a hypothesis. So we have satellites that measure EM radiation.

Hansen goes on to state:

‚ÄúEarth‚Äôs energy imbalance and its changes will determine the future of Earth‚Äôs climate. It is thus imperative to measure Earth‚Äôs energy imbalance and the factors that are changing it.‚Äù
This is true. Because if you don‚Äôt measure the imbalance, you have not confirmed the hypothesis.
Hansen goes on further: ‚ÄúThe required measurement accuracy is ‚àº 0.1 W m‚àí2, in view of the fact that estimated current (2005‚Äì2010) energy imbalance is 0.58 W m-2‚Ä≥.

Hansen then begins to admit the problems with performing the measurements.

‚ÄúThe difficulty with the satellite approach becomes clear by considering first the suggestion of measuring Earth‚Äôs reflected sunlight and emitted heat from a satellite at the Lagrange L1 point, which is a location between the Sun and Earth at which the gravitational pulls from these bodies are equal and opposite. From this location the satellite would continually stare at the sunlit half of Earth. The notion that a single satellite at this point could measure Earth‚Äôs energy imbalance to 0.1 W m ‚àí2 is prima facie preposterous. Earth emits and scatters radiation in all directions, i.e., into 4œÄ steradians. How can measurement of radiation in a single direction provide a proxy for radiation in all directions?‚Äù

‚ÄúIt is implausible that changes in the angular distribution of radiation could be modeled to the needed accuracy, and the objective is to measure the imbalance, not guess at it. There is also the difficulty of maintaining sensor calibrations to accuracy 0.1 W m‚àí2, i.e., 0.04 percent. That accuracy is beyond the state-of-the art, even for short periods, and that accuracy would need to be maintained for decades‚Äù

The above satellite was in a fixed location. Hansen goes on:

‚ÄúThese same problems, the changing angular distribution of the scattered and emitted radiation fields and maintaining extreme precision of sensors over long periods, must be faced by Earth-orbiting satellites‚Äù

‚ÄúThe precision achieved by the most advanced generation of radiation budget satellites is indicated by the planetary energy imbalance measured by the ongoing CERES (Clouds and the Earth‚Äôs Radiant Energy System) instrument (Loeb et al., 2009), which finds a measured 5-yr-mean imbalance of 6.5 W m‚àí2 (Loeb et al., 2009).Because this result is implausible, instrumentation calibration factors were introduced to reduce the imbalance to the imbalance suggested by climate models, 0.85 W m-2‚Ä≥

OK my little religious groupies, what is the problem?"

Because in a direct democracy the people will eventually vote themselves the largess from the wealthy and the country fails. Which in a way is what is happening in the US. In Switzerland, which I'm thinking is where you are from, you have what would best be described as a "representative direct democracy". You still have a Parliament, which would be similar to the Congress of the US, which consist of two houses (the Council of States and the National Council) which would reflect the US Senate and US House of Representatives. Switzerland's Parliament is elected, however, the level of accountability in Switzerland is what I would consider higher because politicians answer more directly to the public, and are much more limited in power than the US. I believe the US form of government that was formed over 200 years ago is a better system of government, but over the last 80 or so years, esp. just before WWII the US began a systematic decline as more and more of the public has become apathetic and thus allowed the US Federal Government to become so large, powerful and burdensome on the population that the US public has become so dependent on the Federal Government that we really no longer have much of a vote in how the country is run. I am what would be considered an "ultra-conservative" by some in the US because I believe in gun rights, freedom from government, and personal responsibility which includes, but is not limited to the right to fail, the right to retain as much as you can from your business ventures, and the right to hold my elected officials accountable for their actions. Unfortunately I am the minority in the US as most people receive some form of government assistance via welfare, medicare/medicaid, social security, public housing, etc., that most people in the US cannot live without the government. I on the other hand am prepared to leave society as a whole, and live with my family away from civilization because at some point a house built out of a deck of cards falls. I see the US failing as a organized government within my lifetime, and have taken steps so the my family can survive as long as possible without any modern infrastructure, and possibly be part of whatever happens after the collapse and reset of the US government, and for that matter humanity in general.

Well, that pretty much describes my views of the world, you might have a little bit better understanding of why global warming is not what concerns me.

author: Aanthanur DC

text:
There is a great deal of noise in short-term predictions. Fluctuations can crowd out the signal from the longer-term trends. Long-term predictions can be far more accurate as short-term factors average out over time.

To put it another way, it is silly to judge someone's long-term model based on their short-term success. Insurance companies make their money based on the fact that, over the long-term, the averages will be borne out, even if, in any given time period, the numbers can be thrown off by miracle or disaster.

Yup, and I give you my detailed analysis of the global warming warmongers and it gets deleted also. So I'll try again....

I have never once said that climate change is not happening. The climate has changed, to extremes, ever since there has been an atmosphere, for some 1 billion years. Life on earf has been around for some 600 million years. There have been at least 5 extinction events that wiped out more than 50% of ALL life in that period, sometimes almost instantly, and man was never ever around to see it or participate in it, much less cause it. I use that to make my point. You believe that increased co2 in the atmosphere by even a tiny amount will be catastrophic. Historically speaking, and not just the last million years, co2 levels have been much much higher than they are now. The earf has had the most biodiversity when co2 levels were well over 1,000 ppm. The highest concentrations of co2 were above 4,000 ppm during the Ordovician- Silurian and the Jurassic-Cretaceous periods. And life did just fine. So, historically speaking, current co2 levels are at least 10 times less than in the past. The last extinction event, but smaller by comparison to the 5 largest, happened about 20,000 years ago when co2 levels dropped to below 200 ppm. Our ancestors were almost wiped out. Plants did not prosper, so there was very very little to eat, for any animals period. Plants prefer co2 above 1,000 ppm, that's why we raise them in green houses. The earf's biosphere adapts to changing climate, hence why the earf doesn't go over a tipping point like Venus, which is in a runaway greenhouse environment, and nothing can survive. So why all the fuss about global warming, climate change and co2? I will tell you that it is not about saving the polar bears, saving the planet, saving oysters, saving our coastlines or saving humanity. it is about power and control. It is about powerful all encompassing government control of our lives because we are not capable of making proper choices for ourselves. We are too stupid, just ask Jonathan Gruber, the architect of Obamacare.

If the only cure to stop anthropogenic global warming didn't involve the extraction of money and wealth from individuals and nations, I would be less suspect. But, when you follow the money and government control infrastructure, the answer is clear.

Let's see how long this stays up before it's deleted...
The global warming warmongers are not about debate, they are about control......

History is full of examples of natural problems caused by humans who were doing what seemed like a good idea at the time, you might for example be familiar with the dust bowls in oklahoma.

The climate of today might well not be the optimal climate for us, but its the one we know and the one we have adapted to. We could probably adapt to other climates, but for other life it may take thouseands of years. It would be a huge gamble.


Lastly you still havent answered whether you think it is a good idea to be as independent as possible of fossil oil or not?
author: Leon K

text:
¬†@De Leon¬†
Seriously, the dust bowl??¬† The dust bowl was caused by a change in the jet stream that lasted from 1931 to 1939. This has happened before this event and man was never here to see it, and it will happen again.

Now to for your answer on oil independence.

The United States no longer imports any oil from the middle east. In fact with the development of the Bakken oil fields in the mid-west, we are starting to export oil around the world. So to answer your question, the US dependence on foreign oil is almost zilch, zero, nada....OPEC can no longer manipulate the price of oil around the world and with the price of oil now below $70/barrel for the first time in 20 years, oil supplies have been stabilized around the world, even with the strife in the middle east.

Now, I will take my tongue out of my cheek, because I know what you were asking.....

Almost every modern technology that we have developed has been because of fossil fuels. If the earth did not have fossil fuels as a inexpensive resource, we would still be living like we did in the early 1800's. There would be no plastics, no computers, no cars, no tv, no electricity, no airplanes, no trains, no satellites, no cell phones, no vaccines, rudimentary healthcare would be the norm, and I'm talking cotton bandages at best. So try living just one day without any of the items I mentioned De. You couldn't do it, unless you lived completely off the grid and had a horse for commuting.

Would it be a good idea to have as little dependence on fossil fuels as possible? Yes. But what in the name of God do you replace it with? We will need oil and fossil fuels until we can harness the power of fusion nuclear reactors. Fission works great, but what do you do with the waste? Fusion produces fantastic amounts of energy with very little waste, but the technology is not within our grasp, mainly because we are too afraid to develop it. Matter-anti-matter reactors could do it. But the Enterprise from Star Trek is centuries from our grasp. So, we have fossil fuels, and that is what we will use until we develop the next generation of energy that is cheaper than fossil fuels, and produces the amounts of energy we need. Fossil fuels will get us to the next generation, we just need to agree on what that will be and move forward. But there will always be trade offs. Nuclear produces waste, wind doesn't produce when it's not windy, hydro(which makes the most sense to me)blocks rivers and alters ecosystems on a grand scale. Solar, the technology doesn't exist to harness the Sun yet cheaply. So we use oil.

Speaking of oil, I need to run into town and get the oil changed in my hot rod that I use to commute 100 miles a day to work and back. Please respond with your thoughts.

McIntyre did this with Mann's HockeyStick garbage and I am extremely grateful for his work and while he get's no pay, no accolades, no position as a watch dog or adviser on how statistics are used, he felt it necessary to do and we should all be grateful that he did it. ¬†But instead, innumerate, illiterate assholes who seem to think writing 'stupid' every third word is a substitute for behaving like a decent human being and approaching the whole subject with an open mind smear him and anyone else who doesn't toe the party line, who doesn't join the certainty bandwagon. ¬†How are you people any different than asshole, fascist Islamists who behead apostates? ¬†The Law prevents you from using a knife but you do your best to attack them in other ways. ¬†Perhaps it's an indication of the smallness of the minds who gravitate so readily to believing CAGW is TRUE AND SETTLED. ¬†Small minds have problems with uncertainty and often will ignore anything that doesn't reach or point towards CERTAINTY. ¬†Yes, you know who you are.

As I have said elsewhere, humans love certainty and that is one of the reasons religion has such a grasp on so many but humans would kill any God(s) if it meant guaranteeing certainty. ¬†It's also why Feynman's remark that there were certain aspects of physics to which he had no answers and he could live with that ignorance, he could live with uncertainty, was so profound. ¬†For some people it seems a real impossibility and they appear like the village mob with pitchforks and axes setting out to settle the damned matter once and for all as long as they can achieve certainty and the one certainty that seems to exist in the universe is destruction and that seems to be where the mad quest for certainty that ignores/sacrifices reality always leads.

Consider that everyone who spends time on climate issues whether directly related or far afield but with some tenuous relationship gets money for what they are doing. ¬†They are making a living, pulling down a salary, getting more funding. And those who might like to do research to question fundamental aspects are denied any funding. ¬†Those who would like to review papers for their statistical robustness must do it on their own time and dollar. ¬†And if these scientists do any research that questions any of the tenets of CAGW, they are attacked, smeared, lied about, threatened, shunned and otherwise treated as pariahs. ¬†And the Michael Manns, the Stephen Schneiders, the Gavin Schmidts, the James Hansens are all too ready to jump to the head of the mob and lead them on a rampage. ¬†And then self-proclaimed experts on youtube and blog sites, that lie and defame and smear, yuck it up and wonder why a paper can't be pulled out to refute every paper ever written that contributes to the hypothesis of CAGW no matter how shoddy that paper might be.

What a bunch of fucking cowards you people are. ¬†Intellectually lazy, sycophantic, fatuous, vacuous, inane bullshit slingers. ¬†Everyone one of you wannabe idiots owes the quality of your life to fossil fuels but you think nothing of demonizing those sources of energy and the people who bring them to you. ¬†What ungrateful, hypocritical twats you all are. ¬†

The great news is that over time your hysterical nonsense will be quashed like an unwelcome stink bug at a picnic.

text:
Let Dr. Crichton educate us:

‚ÄúI want to pause here and talk about this notion of consensus, and the rise of what has been called consensus science. I regard consensus science as an extremely pernicious development that ought to be stopped cold in its tracks. Historically, the claim of consensus has been the first refuge of scoundrels; it is a way to avoid debate by claiming that the matter is already settled. Whenever you hear the consensus of scientists agrees on something or other, reach for your wallet, because you're being had.

Let's be clear: the work of science has nothing whatever to do with consensus. Consensus is the business of politics. Science, on the contrary, requires only one investigator who happens to be right, which means that he or she has results that are verifiable by reference to the real world. In science consensus is irrelevant. What is relevant is reproducible results. The greatest scientists in history are great precisely because they broke with the consensus.


There is no such thing as consensus science. If it's consensus, it isn't science. If it's science, it isn't consensus. Period.‚Äù

Technologyreview is published by MIT, a fundamentalist christian hole-in-the-wall.
------------
A 250 year window to study climate variation is pure flim-flam, especially if one is studying long term trends. ¬†This is what global surface temperature variation looks like since the end of the last Ice Age. (Australia National U. Geosciences Dept - taken from Ice Cores): 10,000 years.

http://jonova.s3.amazonaws.com/graphs/lappi/gisp-last-10000-new.png

(Those guys from Liberty University really get around).
--------
That wild variation follows what? ¬†Must be due to all of those campfires they build during the Holocene. ¬†Or it could be due to solar variation and cosmic ray flux - both of which DIRECTLY affect cloud formation. ¬†The AGW crowd dismisses this by arguing that the variation ITSELF is not enough to account for the temperature variation. ¬†But if you observe the solar/cosmic ray flux effect on cloud formation (this involves subatomic particle interaction in the upper atmosphere), it accounts for global surface temperature variation PERFECTLY. (Danish Meteorological Institute). ¬†
This data and model have now been so well refined that we are able to ACCURATELY predict global temperatures for at least 2 decades and are close to being able to do so for 100 years. ¬†This is called model VALIDATION, a fundamental requirement of what used to be science. ¬†AGW makes excuses.¬†

text:
The New Scientific Method: Delphi Fallacies as Facts
1. Make Observations
2. Formulate a Hypothesis, being sure that positive results validate your hypothesis while any negative results can be explained away. ¬†Ignore any variables than are poorly understood. ¬†Don't get too specific. ¬†
3. Test the Hypothesis in Nature. ¬†But remember, models supersede nature/experimentation.
4. Examine the Results of the Experiment. ¬†
5. If too many of the results and variables don't align themselves with the hypothesis, ignore them or/and get Hollywood to make a movie to pave over those inconveniences.
6. When confronted with inconsistencies, lie and belittle.
7. Bury and/or massage data as needed because the "politics" of AGW is more important than a few gaps in what we think understand. (We of course know it's only a few).
8. ¬†If any scientists disagree with this and argue that at our current state of understanding, what drives GW is beyond our complexity horizon - Please see #6.
9. Truth is better served not by evidence but by public relations.
10. When all else fails, fall back upon: "Yes we'd all like better evidence, but if we're right and we do nothing...

The models and explanations keep getting more complex and sophisticated in order to explain why previous predictions don't pan out. And then there's Al Gore. The man is unstable. Anthropogenically? Maybe, perhaps CO2 is playing a higher order role, but I don't think it's the main driver. What really concerns me about your side of the argument is the totalitarian-like tactics in play to squash the debate. The 97% consensus figure is a complete joke. So, in the end, it comes down to trust. Although I am a scientist and engineer by trade, I am not a climate expert nor do I have the time to become one. text:
¬†@Yiannis Mihail¬†¬†Alright Yiannis, let's stick with some pretty simple facts. What has surface temperature of the Earth done in the last 15 or so years? Has it declined? I believe it has. Has CO2 emissions decreased or increased during this time? I believe they have continued to increased. Fifteen years is a negligible amount of geological time, but it is a rather large percentage of time relative to the beginning of the industrial age. So, if CO2 is a first order factor in surface temperature, why has mean surface temperature decreased? It seems to me that it should continue to steadily rise. I think climate scientist have a good "hand waving" explanation for this, but I'm not buying it. What it tells me is that they don't really have a clue or they're operating with other motives. Either way, I'm not convinced.¬†

Yes, the year to year weather patterns are changing, but isn't that just what happens? The Earth is a dynamic and complex system. Drought and famine have been part Man's history and it will be ever more.¬†

As far as peer review goes doesn't there exist a group of these guys that peer review each other? How valid is that? I don't think there is a conspiracy, but I do think they support each other. And it's big money (~$70,000,000,000 in U.S. Federal dollars given to climate scientists from 2008 to 2012). ¬†I'm sure you've heard and read about climate-gate, right? Although, the scientists were vindicated from fraud, it does bring into question their competency and motives. And you call me naive?¬†

By the way, where are people being tortured by the weather?

Historically, the claim of consensus has been the first refuge of scoundrels; it is a way to avoid debate by claiming that the matter is already settled. text:
¬†@N Marbletoe¬† ¬†@Yiannis Mihail¬†¬†
OK Marbletoe, I'll at least give you credit for trying. So I will respond.

Why is point 1. irrelevant? That might be the most important point of all. You actually got close to answering it when you responded to point 3. (plant a billion trees). So here is how the two connect.

Plants need large amounts of co2 to survive. In fact most plants prefer co2 levels that are around 800 ppm, about twice what it is now, and that is why we create artificial environments to grow healthy plants.

Since plants like somewhat higher co2 levels than we have currently, as co2 rises, more plants will grow and produce more oxygen. However, planting a "billion trees" is not the answer. The oceans are the answer. Microscopic plants in the oceans create more oxygen and lock up more carbon than all the plants and trees on land combined!! The earf has this nice balance of power tug of war going on and it keeps our ecosystems in relative harmony. Even when a super volcano erupts, asteroid hits, and prolonged ice ages come about, the earf finds a way to balance it out. My contention is that even if we artificially raise co2 in the atmosphere, it isn't necessarily a bad thing. Also, global warming is not happening in the respect that it is portrayed.

As more sea ice melts, it changes the salinity of the oceans, thus changing ocean currents. The biggest effect currently to the climate is the Thermohaline circulation of the oceans. Here is a short excerpt from a scientific article about it.

"The adjective thermohaline derives from thermo- referring to temperature and -haline referring to salt content, factors which together determine the density of sea water. Wind-driven surface currents (such as the Gulf Stream) travel polewards from the equatorial Atlantic Ocean, cooling en route, and eventually sinking at high latitudes (forming North Atlantic Deep Water). This dense water then flows into the ocean basins. While the bulk of it upwells in the Southern Ocean, the oldest waters (with a transit time of around 1000 years) upwell in the North Pacific. Extensive mixing therefore takes place between the ocean basins, reducing differences between them and making the Earth's oceans a global system. On their journey, the water masses transport both energy (in the form of heat) and matter (solids, dissolved substances and gases) around the globe. As such, the state of the circulation has a large impact on the climate of the Earth".

In short, as the oceans salinity is changed by adding more fresh water, the ocean currents then change, and the result is a cooling affect, which then adds more ice to the poles, increasing ocean salinity and so on. Things get thrown somewhat out of balance when there is to much cooling, co2 levels drop dramatically to less than half current levels and you have runaway cooling resulting in an ice age that lasts for tens of centuries or longer. It is not until the co2 levels begin to rise, and the earf warms that the climate becomes more like it is now.

I postulate that by artificially adding co2, we will bring the earf back into an ice age quicker than it would normally, say in 10 to 15 thousand years from now, instead of 30 to 80 thousand years, which would be the historic normal cycle. There is also evidence that this cooling affect is starting to happen now, as the winters of the last few years have been much colder than normal, esp. in the northern hemisphere. I had never ever heard of the term "Polar Vortex" until last winter, have you??¬† We are even seeing that happen now, as the mid-west is currently trapped in unseasonably cold weather 20 to 30 degrees below normal for early fall.

What say you??
author: danahan01

text:
¬†@danahan01¬†¬†Well aren't you something different from your run of the mill deniers!!!. Definitely a pleasure then to reason this, although unscientifically, with you.

You are right. Plants do thrive on higher concentrations of CO2. Unfortunately, humans don't and that's why we don't live in greenhouses. By the time the plants catch up with the rise of CO2, assuming of course we let them which we won't as we don't already, there might be some mammals on the planet to enjoy the CO2 free atmosphere. I doubt it will be humans.¬†

02 produced in the sea is due to algae which are dying because of the constant temperature rise of the sea further exacerbating the problem.

Currents. By changing/stopping the currents you are only changing the distribution of heat. That means that you will have places in the North with a heck of a lot colder climate, (for as long as that lasts) and places in the equator which will positively boil. HOWEVER, the NET result on the average GLOBAL temperature remains unchanged and RISING.

What you don't seem to understand, probably because you are not aware of how evolution works, is that it takes many thousands of years for species to become acclimatized to the new conditions. That is why (actually its the reverse and that's why life was possible on earth until now, but its funny to reverse the sequence) climate changes in the past took, as you mentioned 30-80k years. Consider that homo sapiens alone has been around for roughly 200k years. Imagine the time scale. ¬†Then do the climate change in the real blink of the eye which has been the last 200 years. There is the problem. And don't think we will be fine because we have AC. We still need to eat and the rest of the animal kingdom hasn't, till now, discovered electricity to run their climate control systems.

As to your 3, you have been fed lies by the people that would have you brush this off as another conspiracy by your communist leader (LOL), playing on the usual american lack of education and pre-conditioned fear of the reds!!!
TRUTH: Sustainable energy sources are cheaper, will produce much more wealth for far greater numbers of your co-patriots (not just the factory owners and the oil moguls) and are... SUSTAINABLE. Like it or not, your petrol and coal will run out well before 2050. What are you going to do then?¬†
author: Yiannis Mihail

text:
¬†@danahan01¬†¬†ok, i see how point 1 is relevant to temp change, because of Co2 feedback. ¬†i thought you just meant Co2 is good for agriculture, and just bcs something is good for plants doesn't mean it's good for the climate... however, feedback is important, the 'tug of war' you mention, so i'll give you point 1. ¬†feedbacks are probably the least reliable part of climate models. ¬†

Agree the thermohaline circulation seems very important in causing abrupt swings in temperature. ¬†That's not very comforting, however. ¬†At least with a steady warming or cooling, we could get used to it... ¬†I agree we could be heading to an ice age, and warming/ Co2 increase could actually help trigger it, though i think that's an open question. ¬†Until we can hind-cast with accuracy things like the ridiculously fast warmup 15,000 ya, the models have little chance at extrapolation outside of historical conditions. ¬†

"evidence that this cooling effect is starting..." ¬†idk, it was cold in the 48 last winter, but warm in Alaska and Canada. ¬†And warm globally. ¬†I actually predicted the polar vortex (not by name, which i did not hear before) last summer... on the assumption that arctic temps would be warm and this would de-stabilize the polar front, letting cold air slip down into the temperate zone. ¬†My prediction was "snownados" and "blizzicanes" -- mixing of summer and winter effects, and i think was right. ¬†So warming in the arctic i think is consistent with cold winters at mid latitudes. ¬†

That doesn't really negate your point, because regional effects could trigger an ice age even if the planet were on a warming trend as a whole. ¬†

A point about the oceans:¬†acidification. ¬†This could be a problem no matter what the temperature does. ¬†They are acidifying already, and we don't really know how much acid corals etc can survive. ¬†That's one of many non-warming-related reasons to decrease fossil fuels and plant trees... ¬†

"planting a billion trees is not the answer" ¬†Agree that ocean productivity is more important than land. ¬†Oceans are decreasing productivity now; not a good thing. ¬†I hate the idea some suggest of dumping iron into the ocean to increase productivity; geo engineering imho is more likely to go wrong than right. ¬†Guaranteed they'll end up dumping it on some poor whale, or making red tides or some shit. ¬†Trees can be sequester a lot of carbon and even if that is a moot point, they help local economies and have lots of other good effects. ¬†I'd be for it if we're talking native trees, not another damn introduced species plantation. ¬†

I Agree with danahan01 that it's quite interesting engaging with you on this issue. ¬†I've already learned a few things this morning. ¬†Now i have a question; you say "global warming is not happening in the respect that it is portrayed." ¬†Can explain that?

author: Andrew Mirlach

text: Amongst the problems with getting an accurate public understanding of global warming is that it has several of the most difficult aspects of scientific theories (several shared by evolution). It deals with long trends, using data that is not directly perceived by humans in one locale, but rather averaged over vast areas and numerous observations. It requires statistical modeling of diverse measures to see those trends and their impact. It is entirely understandable that there is a vigorous skeptical group that questions various aspects of the theory. Every aspect: anthropogenic and global and warming is questioned by some group. I honestly don't think the reason for the skepticism is widespread disinformation conspiracies or big oil. It is just a very abstract data set, impossible to substantiate with a sound bite or even with an hour long program. It sounds, on first encounter, precisely like the apocalyptic nonsense spewed by the religious for millennia. Much better education and more clever methods of summarizing the data are needed to make the supporting data and concepts more readily available to the general public.

author: Andrew Mirlach

text: Global climatic warm periods caused them, themselves mostly due to our planets orbit and it's rotation axis precessing. Volcanic activity also played a role probably. But there is one observation that offsets all your examples from the current rise in temperature. All the past warming events took place over vastly longer periods of time. Warming by ~1C in  about a century (give or take) is orders of magnitude faster than anything we see in the geological record. I'm certainly open for debate, but let's get to the meat of the issue: if I'm wrong, climate change won't happen, and worst outcome is that we built the renewables we need eventually faster than necessary. If you are wrong we run the risk of extinction, at the most extreme, but massive environmental and social damage at least. Is this a risk worth taking?

text: Some stuff is considered a public good ¬†and other stuff as private goods. ¬†The environment is generally a public good in our culture. ¬†Those private interests that have trillions of dollars at stake, for example the fossil fuels industries, are highly motivated to get concessions from the public realm. ¬†Public goods like the environment belong to all individuals. ¬†Their value is spread out among us. ¬†So, if the private interest is highly motivated to lobby for their benefit, who is highly motivated to lobby for the public interest? ¬†Concentrated benefits for the few to take from the public weal, ¬†dispersed costs for the members of the group who lose a portion of their public good. ¬†And, if a few people do provide a public good, they will only get to enjoy that benefit as much as those who do not provide it. ¬†So, many folks will sit back and let others provide for the public well-being. ¬†This is a societal freerider problem in western civilization. ¬† Scientists who critique and peer review one another are providing a public good, information with which to make decisions for the well being of the group. ¬†And when way over 90% of these data-examining professionals concur that human caused climate change is a very serious situation, and they are not saying this for a private interest, ¬†but they are overcoming the freerider problem and are supporting the public welfare, this should be a huge clue that we all should pay attention to and work for our public welfare by asking our leaders to honestly pay attention. ¬†Can we at least ask for honest public oversight of climate change ? ¬†For the public weal ? ¬† Lets try.

text: It's clear that climate change deniers are not scientists, they are ideologues who only talk in terms of anecdotal evidence. Understanding global warming really is simple. Scientists know exactly how CO2 gas behaves (the physics of gases are very precisely understood). Unlike other atmospheric gases like oxygen, nitrogen, and argon, CO2 absorbs radiation as heat. The balance elevation where the radiation striking the earth and being emitted back into space goes higher as CO2 builds up in the atmosphere. The average temperature of the earth's surface increases in direct proportion to this rise in elevation of the radiation balance point. The rise in temperature at the surface causes more water to evaporate, and water vapor also absorbs radiation as heat, multiplying the heating. This much is known for certain. We only don't know exactly how much the various multiplier effects will come into play, and we can only hope that those effects will not be as much as this speaker, and many of the rest of us, are afraid is the case. No matter what, we've got to act to forestall this.

text: Climate change is not simple; in fact it's extremely complex and way beyond the ken our IPCC''s computer models. Notwithstanding what Al Gore says, there is a great deal of uncertainty about what the precise relationship between greenhouse gases and temps are. For example, the past 13 years have seen no significant increase in global temperature, despite the significant increase in greenhouse gases emitted into the atmosphere during that time frame. The computer model forecasts have been wrong. Why is that? Maybe, some speculate (and I emphasize speculate), the oceans are trapping the heat. Maybe. Maybe it has something to do with sunspots and solar flares. Maybe. Maybe it has something to do with clouds and water vapor. Maybe. The point is that no one really can explain this unexpected phenomenon. There is much more we don't know about climate change than people like David Roberts will acknowledge. So before we ask every person on the globe to sacrifice a higher standard of living for the sake of some doomsday future 100 years from now as projected by a computer model, let's admit what we don't know and try to figure out how to fill in the gaps.

text: As I indicated earlier, after it becomes too cold, much of the new land ice comes from oceans falling from beneath sea ice; depositing what was once sea ice on newly dry land. Wide ranging temperatures this cold were only really prevalent during the snowball earth(s). But that was what I said in the first place.
author: Nate Drake

text: -10C is the equilibrium temperature for ice sheet building. This is the temperature of optimal precipitation accumulation to ablation ratio on Ice sheets. as it gets colder the amount of precipitation drops. As temperatures drop, not only does the rate of accumulation from precip drop, so does sea level. After a certain point it is not so much seas being deposited on top of ice sheets, but frozen seas becoming land ice as oceans fall from beneath them.
author: Nate Drake

text: Not by magic, by initially high levels of precipitation, and then once it becomes prohibitively cold by the diamond dust phenomena and sheer freezing. If you have the chance to witness diamond dust in person (e.g. dead of winter in Yellowstone, or a trip to Antarctica) it is really quite beautiful. During most periods there is still warm enough air to allow for some precipitation, but in a full snowball earth, there wasn't.
author: Nate Drake

text: Yes, condensation actually cannot happen in the real atmosphere until supersaturation occurs (>100%) If a parcel of air has 95% of its total water capacity, it will just stay as saturated air. The only real exception is when it becomes so cold that all moisture instantly freezes (called diamond dust) This diamond dust phenomena is actually the major way ice gets deposited during very cold times (glacial periods) and the dominant source of firn deposition in Antarctica now.

Greenland) receives much more precipitation (5 feet / year) than a tremendously cold one (E.G. Antarctica) which receives much less (1 inch per year). text: False, you need to improve your math literacy. a 6% increase in atmospheric moisture does not result in a 6% increase in precipitation (your example, 5% of the 30 in of snow). Atmospheric dynamics at the weather scale are non-linear.

It's similar to the argument from authority, true, but I'm not making a truth claim, just a risk assessment.

Temperatures much below 0C ensures that the air is DRY for at that temperature WV cannot exist (Antarctica is the driest continent)
When cold dry air meets warm moist air you get snow.
So snowy winters tend to temper the cold air

text: Without the atmosphere, the Earth's surface would receives an average of 335 W/m^2. Assuming it behaved like a black body, that would give an average surface temperature less than 4¬∫C (39¬∫F). Considering we can measure the Earth's average temperature to currently be around 15¬∫C, clearly the atmosphere keeps us warmer than would otherwise be the case. The more greenhouse gases we add, the warmer it'll keep us. That's climate change in a nutshell.
